title: Great Music Debates: Which is the greatest rock band of all time? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Unquestionably the Beatles. John, Paul, George and Ringo sit heads and shoulders above the rest. Here’s several reasons why: Influence: In the 1960s & 70s, everyone wanted to look, act, and sound like the Beatles: haircuts, beads, Neru Jackets, etc. They opened people’s mind politically and socially. And the list of artists that they directly influenced is endless: from Aha, Billy Joel, the Clash, Don McClean, Erasure, Frankie Goes to Hollywood, Greenday, Howard Jones, INXS, Jet, … Prince, Queen, the Ramones, Squeeze, Tom Petty, U2, Vapors, Wham!, XTC, Yaz and Zebra. They led the first British Invasion to America, and by many accounts are responsible for influencing the 2nd British Invasion (‘80’s New Wave). The 1967 BBC broadcast of “Our World” was the first global satellite music event for which the Beatles composed “All You Need is Love”; hundreds of millions around the world tuned in. Kids born 30 years after the last Beatles song was recorded, know and are familiar with at least some of their most popular songs. You can’t say that for most bands.Record sales: Top 5 songs simultaneously in Billboard’s Top 100; until Michael Jackson’s Thriller, no one sold more records. In just 7 years they recorded 7 albums, 22 singles, 4 EPs, and made 4 movies. They traditional songs into hits (“Happy Birthday”, “My Bonnie”). Even average / not great albums went platinum. As hinted in the song “Sgt. Pepper” (“It was 2- years ago today ….”), 20 years after each single was recorded Apple issued a picture disc 45rpm record that had the picture from the 45-jacket embedded on the disc. They sold out instantly and became highly sought after collectibles.Talent: Substantial roots (American rock-n-roll), fertile grounds (Merseyside in Northern England) and great timing (1960’s) aside, these 4 boys had genuine talent; each went on to superstar solo careers. They wrote their own songs at a time when record companies dictated what the artists would perform. Not just Lennon & McCarthy, but the distinct genius of George Harrison. And they wrote other artists’ material (Marvelettes, Anne Murray, Rolling Stones, etc.).Musical Evolution: Their music, with inclusion of other styles, experimentation, and innovation never before seen defines musical evolution: early raw rock, quiet folk rock, introspective blues, country cross over, soft ballads, power ballads, fun goofy songs, complex rock (laying the foundation for album oriented rock), genuine quotable poetry and inspirational story telling. They blazed new trails, added Piccolo trumpet (Penny Lane), Sitar (Norwegian Wood), Recorder (Fool On The Hill), and other instruments to popular songs. They invented the concept album (Sgt. Pepper), parodied themselves (Yellow Submarine), and got a 7 minute song on the radio (Hey Jude) at a time when radio stations refused to play anything more than 3–1/2 minutes. Then they created their own record label.Humble Beginnings: 4 poor lads from Liverpool; no money, no training, no plan, and two of the 4 came from single parent homes. Against these odds arose a band that changed the world.Global Appeal: They started in Liverpool, England, honed their craft in Hamburg, Germany, conquered America, and then toured the world. They even recorded songs in German.Revered by their peers: Other successful musicians praised them publicly; Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, Ray Charles, Marvin Gaye, Bob Dylan and Mick Jagger among them. They were known to perform and collaborate with Eric Clapton, Elton John, Billy Preston, Jimmy Page, Michael Jackson, Stevie Wonder, Billy Joel, Sting, Tom Petty and Roy Orberson.Cross-Discipline Realities: Is there another Rock-n-Roll band that can prove a mathematical law? The Beatles, Wings, John Lennon, George Harrison, and Ringo Star from 1960 - 1998 proved unequivocally that “The whole is greater than the sum of it’s parts”.A Social Statement: The Beatles were more than a rock band. Like all great artists, they both expressed and reflected the times they lived in. They defined the 1960s and shaped the 70s & 80s. Song title phrases like Working Class Hero, All You Need is Love, Give Peace a Chance, You Say You Want a Revolution?, and Let it Be all resonate in the hearts and minds of those who grew up in the 1960s, 70s and 80s. They paved the way for Bob Geldorf (Band Aid), U2 and other politically sensitive artists to thrive while sending their message.Summary: While there were lots of great rock bands that added incredible color dimension and advancement to rock-n-roll in their own right, there is not a single other band that offered each of the categories above. The appropriate parable in Baseball is Babe Ruth: He was the one of the most incredible hitters that ever played the game and simultaneously one of the most incredible pitchers that ever played the game. The Beatles are the Babe Ruth of rock music

I would like to take the name of not 1 but 3 top bands for me and for most of the people all around the world: 1) The BeatlesThey are unquestionably the best and most important band in rock history, as well as the most compelling story. Almost miraculously, they embodied the apex of the form artistically, commercially, culturally and spiritually at just the right time, the tumultuous '60s, when music had the power to literally change the world (or at least to give the impression that it could, which may be the same thing). The Beatles are the archetype: there is no term in the language analogous to “Beatlemania.” The Beatles generated an intensity of joy that slapped tens of millions of people in the face with the awareness that happiness and exuberance were not only possible, but in their presence, inevitable. They generated an energy that was amplified a million times over and returned to them in a deafening tidal wave of grateful hysteria. 2) Led Zeppelin Over a 10-year, nine-album career from 1969-79, Led Zeppelin was the most popular rock group in the world, ultimately selling more than 50 million records in the U.S. alone (more than 200 million worldwide), developing the blues-based power trio-plus-lead singer archetype in many directions including mystical English folk-rock, Middle Eastern-influenced exotica, quirky pop and every manner of heaviness. They also came to symbolize the Dionysian excesses of the rock lifestyle. 3) Pink FloydPink Floyd is the most eccentric and experimental multi-platinum band of the album rock era, creating exceptional cinematic sound sculptures “Meddle,” “Dark Side of the Moon,” “Wish You Were Here,” and the band’s popular apex and conceptual death knell, “The Wall.” They well-known rock bands of the progressive rock genre, capturing the essence of lengthy instrumental passages and complementing them with memorable vibes and clear lyrics. Their concepts were compelling, from early psychedelic eccentricities to the formation of a concept album.

My list and ranking of the greatest , best , and my most favourite rock bands of all time , in respective order , and why I think they are the best are : 1) The Beatles - The songwriting partnership of Lennon - McCartney duo (credited to the members of The Beatles and English musicians : John Lennon and Paul McCartney) is fantastic and the greatest (in my opinion) , released great and widely influential albums in the late 1960’s (most notably being : Sgt Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band (1967) , and Abbey Road (1969) , wrote simple songs that had not too enough complex compositions that topped the US Billboard charts , were the progenitors / revolutionized and innovated the idea of an “ album ’’ to be the most dominant and important form in music rather than a “ single ’’ , were also the progenitors / revolutionized and innovated the idea of playing in front of a live audience at the stadium (most notably playing the 1st ever stadium show and were the 1st ever stadium music acts to play at the famous Shea Stadium concert in 1965) and how the music should be recorded , their ability to shed / shun and diminish their celebrity image from the “ 4 mop tops who had huge popularity in the early 1960’s “ Beatlemania ’’ as “ teen idols ’’ to the real musicians they became while shedding their former images while producing and releasing the greatest rock records of all time ’’. 2) Queen - The stage presence and vocal “ singing ’’ skills along with innovating and changing the way how frontman should act and dress on stage of Freddie Mercury (the lead vocalist “ singer ’’ / frontman of Queen) , the guitar playing skills of Brian May (the lead guitarist of Queen) which in my opinion is vastly underrated , the multi-talented Roger Taylor (drummer of Queen) who is also hugely underrated , Their ability and talent to write and compose complex structured songs that appeal to both masses and classes while becoming anthems worldwide for sporting events (most notably being “ Bohemian Rhapsody ’’ , “ We Will Rock You / We Are The Champions ’’) , Their live stage performances together while performing as a band (most notably being in the 1985 Live Aid). 3) Led Zeppelin - The electrifying stage presence and wide vocal “ singing ’’ range along with changing the way how frontman should act of Robert Plant (the lead vocalist “ singer ’’ / frontman of Led Zeppelin) , the extremely significant and best guitar playing innovative skills and techniques of Jimmy Page (the lead guitarist and founder of Led Zeppelin) , the best drumming skills in fast speed which are uncomparable of John Bonham (drummer of Led Zeppelin) , Their live stage performances together while performing as a band , composing and writing “ Stairway To Heaven ’’ which is considered to be one of the greatest rock songs of all time. 4) The Rolling Stones - The great combination of musical collaboration on their music and even while performing together on stage / live for the band between the frontman / lead vocalist “ singer ’’ Mick Jagger and lead guitarist Keith Richards , Their (and all the band members : Mick Jagger on lead vocals , Keith Richards on lead guitar , Brian Jones on many other different instruments (till his death) , Charlie Watts on drums , Bill Wyman on bass guitar , and Ronnie Wood also on lead guitar) experience of  live stage performances together as a band , shedding and successfully reducing and removing their celebrity images (along with their rivals , The Beatles) from “ bad boys / and teen idols ’’ to “ great yet hugely successful live musical act that produced sensible and self composed / written records ’’. 5) U2 - The passionate yet spiritual-like sounding vocals of Bono (lead vocalist “ singer ’’ / frontman of U2) , Their live stage performances together while performing as a band (most notably having multiple highest grossing concert tours to their name) ,

In no order, who would you say are the top five rock bands of all time? I’m going to look at this in terms of influence on the industry, other artists, and creativity, not just on popularity or who sold the most concert tickets or albums. The Beatles - Just think about what they did in such a short amount of time and the bands that credit them as a major influence in their own careers. They continue to define rock 50+ years after forming.Led Zeppelin - Few bands have been as widely imitated as Led Zeppelin. Their music dominated Album Oriented Rock stations and continues to be played today.Nirvana - I don’t think that the Grunge movement in music would have been as huge as it was without Nirvana, and this band permanently changed the face of rock.The Clash - A punk band with social statement undertones, during their heyday they were called “The Only Band That Matters” by many in the industry.The Ramones - One of my favorite bands to see play live. Their 3 chord, 3 minute max songs just rocked. They were the original punk band and it was a nice escape from the hell that was disco in the 70’s. Among the groups that have credited The Ramones influence are Green Day and one of my favorites U2. In an interview for Time magazine, U2’s lead singer Bono said of the Ramones "When we first formed the band, Adam and I were 16, Edge was 15, and Larry was 14, and we were fans of the Ramones. They kind of stopped the world long enough for bands like U2 and others to get on... We were a band before we could play. We formed our band around an idea of friendship and shared spirit. That was a preposterous notion before the Ramones."Honorable mentions: The Rolling StonesThe WhoFleetwood MacBob Marley & The WailersThe White Stripes

Alright, here’s my top 10 best rock bands of all time - 1- Led Zeppelin- Absolutely no room for argument here. Robert Plant on vocals and Jimmy Page on the guitar and John Bonham on the drums was an utterly sick partnership. Extra-ordinarily creative as these dudes were and mind-numbingly sensational, this band had it all- lyrics, attitude, insane skill to develop the kind of music nobody ever could during the 70’s. 2- Pink Floyd- My mind is always in a battle to decide who should be number 1, Zeppelin or Pink Floyd. Probably both these legendary bands should be placed at a similar pedestal for the kind contribution they’ve made to rock in their own ways. “Comfortably numb” and “Wish you were here” still remain one of my all-time favorite rock songs. 3 -Queen - Ahhh!! Queen- I’ve always been such a massive fan of Freddie Mercury and his band. Freddie was the soul of this band, super energetic voice and an indefatigable performer. This was such a complete band. “Under Pressure” and “Don’t stop me now” are my favorites. 4- The Beatles- Probably the band with best singers on it in Paul Mccartney and John Lenon. These prodigious legends will always be irreplaceable. There are so many songs of them that I absolutely love, If I have to name one its gotta be “Hey Jude”. 5- Avenged Sevenfold- You must be wondering who the fuck are these guys. I wont say much about them. Just check them out once if you haven’t yet and I can promise you that wont be disappointed. Start with these tracks- So far away, Seize the day, and A little piece of heaven. This is one hell of a band which holds a really special space in my heart. Solid lyrics, insane guitarists, probably had one of THE BEST drummers on the band. RIP Jimmy Sullivan. I know, I said I wouldn’t say much about them, But couldn’t resist. Another reason this band is so fucking good is because its probably among the very few modern bands which still consistently makes fantastic rock stuff even today, in a time where we are surrounded with garbage musicians making utter garbage, bands like these remind us that rock is still alive. 6- Radiohead- Plain genius. Beautiful and classical compositions coupled with lyrics so cryptic, deep and nonchalant that will make you completely lost. Their track “Creep” has to be in the rock hall of fame for being one of the greatest rock songs of all time. I could listen to it all day. 7- Red Hot Chili Peppers- C’mon! who does not love RHCP. “Californication” Don't forget me” “Under the bridge” “Can’t stop” “Snow”, so many brilliant songs. Has to be at 6th for me. Long live RHCP! 8-Nirvana- Another great band, their heavy lyrics with some intense inclusion of grunge rock rightfully earned them an unparalleled cult following which is still growing today. 9- Foo fighters- Was a really difficult choice to make. To place them on 9th on the list was a bit tricky for me, but nevertheless, a good band who made some great songs over the years. I always was a big admirer of Dave Grohl since his Nirvana days. Their new album was a bummer though. 10- I can't think of a band that should be 10th on my list. There are so many names that are popping up in my head. Will probably update once I zero in on a band worthy of a 10th spot.

Was The Beatles a rock band or a pop band? The Beatles was surely the best band so far, so if they were a rock band, then they are number 1. But, generally speaking, rock lists don’t tend to include them, so I’ll leave them out for now. Just put them back in at #1 if you consider them to be a rock band. ‘Of all time’ means ‘of all time so far’. In which case: #1 Led Zeppelin. There was a world pre-Zeppelin, and there was a world post-Zeppelin. They changed everything, more than anyone else did, ever. At least as far as rock bands are concerned. #2 The Rolling Stones. I was never a fan — born at the wrong time — but for pure bandsmanship, they out-showed everyone else. I could put Queen in that slot for the same reason, but the Stones were, well, the Stones. #3 U2. Again, I wasn’t really a fan in the 1980s, but this is the only band which has been at the forefront of relevance for almost forty years. In terms of longevity without ever becoming a self-tribute act, these are the greatest. Bands that were amazing bands but couldn’t qualify for the ‘greatest’ in any of these three criteria include: Queen: glamorous, exquisite musicians, innovators. But they can’t out-Zeppelin Zeppelin for musical ability, and they didn’t out-showman the Stones.Pink Floyd: so, so good, just not the top.Fleetwood Mac: Rumours is still one of the greatest albums ever, but their other material didn’t live up to it.Dire Straits. Amazing, and coming back into fashion, but they were also on the borders between rock and pop. If they’d ever turned it right up…Lynyrd Skynyrd. What could they have become if it weren’t for that aircrash?Genesis. Another superb band.The Police. I so much wanted to put these in the top three, but couldn’t achieve it.The Ramones. Think the Sex Pistols invented punk? Forget it, the Ramones were there long before them.Evanescence. One amazing album. But the tension between the leaders died when one of them left, and nothing they made after that was the same.Florence and the Machine. Lots of time yet for Florence Welch to make that definitive statement… here’s hoping.Black Sabbath. If Zeppelin didn’t invent heavy metal, then Sabbath did. But unlike Zeppelin, they stayed in one place.The Who. Eclipsed by their peers, they still had everything, maybe not quite in the same quantities as the top three.Status Quo. For many people, Status Quo was rock music.The Jimi Hendrix Experience. If it wasn’t for the name, this band would get a lot more credit. They were three outstanding musicians. Everyone talks about Hendrix. I think if he had lived longer, the band would have established more of its own identity.The Yardbirds. Jeff Beck, Eric Clapton and Jimmy Page all got their starts here. No other band was the beginning of so much.Van Halen. They seem a bit 80s now, but, back in the 80s… well, they rocked.

It is so subjective to give a definitive answer for this. The great rock bands can be judged on so much criteria. Here are my answers for different reasons. The Beatles - They had such a wide variety of styles. A band that was only making albums for 7 years and had a mass following because of the quality of the music primarily. They are also the first band to really get popular writing their own songs. The personalities of each member of the band is known well by just about anyone alive right now. They broke up over 40 years ago and people of all ages love them just as much today as they ever did. AC/DC - The great simple hard rock band. These guys found something they were good at and stuck with it. They are as great today as they were in the 70s. They are still the greatest heavy rock band around, and their sound has not changed one iota. Led Zeppelin - The learned thinkers of rock. Played solidly and didn't give in to studio commercialism to release singles. They made it solely on albums. That's pretty impressive if you think about it. Plus the music has a driving power and thoughtful solemnity that overshadows all bands that came after them. The Who - We wouldn't have stage antics like guitar smashing without them. The music is solid, expertly written, produced, and performed. They are alos the loudest band in the world. That has to count for something. Queen - The showman playboys of rock. No band has ever, or will ever, match the true showmanship of this band. They had an awesome sound that is practically timeless and they can also boast the greatest front man who ever lived. Freddie Mercury is the most profuse singer in the history of popular music. Rolling Stones / U2 / Pearl Jam - I'm am calling a three way tie for these guys. Why? They have stuck it out for a long time. Sure there have been line up changes or long breaks, but all three have continued to make new music and haven't lessened in quality. That's a real tough thing to accomplish. U2 are the longest lasting band without a line up change. A lot of people on here have put forward Bob Dylan. He's not a band, he's a singer/songwriter. Also, he's not best known for his rock music. He's a folk genius, don't get me wrong, but I can't put him on a list of great rock bands. Just my opinion. Hope this answer is helpful to anyone.

Original question: Who do you think are/were the greatest rock bands of all time, and why? Yes, I do think The Who were the greatest rock band of all time. Not long ago, after watching an interview with Chuck Klosterman, I went out and bought his latest book: But What If We're Wrong? The idea that Klosterman explores in this book is to understand how the present might be viewed a couple of centuries in the future, when it has become the past. It's an interesting conceit. In the second chapter, which talks about music, Klosterman suggests that the story of rock and roll (or rock 'n' roll, or just rock) is likely to be told by focusing on a single iconic musician. He provides some good arguments in favor of his choice for this iconic rocker: Chuck Berry. And when a pop-culture expert (and the author of both Fargo Rock City and Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs) makes a pronouncement like that, you have to consider it pretty seriously. And make no mistake about it, Chuck Berry was fantastic. But, in this case, Klosterman's wrong. And, of course, given the structure/nature of his book, he might even agree with me when I say that he's wrong. To fully understand the argument, you have to imagine that it's the 23rd century. (The Enterprise has presumably just left on its five-year mission to boldly go where no man has gone before.) You're putting together the syllabus for a course called something like "The History of Popular Music in the Western World". You've already finished the lecture on "March", which is personified, as everyone knows, by John Philip Sousa. (This is the example that Klosterman provides for how our present has simplified its view of this part of the past history of music.) You then cover "Ragtime", which is personified by Scott Joplin. (You, the present day reader rather than the 23rd century music scholar, might think that ragtime would be better personified by Jelly Roll Morton. And you're right about the greatness of Jelly Roll Morton, of course, but still wrong nevertheless. Our present has already decided that Joplin is Ragtime.) The next lecture obviously has to cover "Jazz". I admit that I can't figure out if jazz will be personified by Louie Armstrong, Duke Ellington, or Miles Davis. This difficulty probably results from the fact that we're still a little too close (historically) to jazz for this distillation to have taken place. Maybe jazz can get two lectures (between the two world wars, personified by Ellington, and after World War II, personified by Davis). But eventually, you have to put together the lecture on "Rock". And so, to help you along, I've compiled a list to help persuade you that you should tell the story of rock using The Who as the canonical/iconic example. Rock is primarily the product of bands, not of individual musicians. And The Who, obviously, are a band.The heart of rock and roll lives in England. (Pacem, Huey Lewis. It's not in New York or LA or even Austin.) The Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Kinks, the Animals, the Yardbirds, Pink Floyd, Led Zeppelin.... And, of course, The Who.Woodstock. Festivals are an important factor in the history of rock. And Woodstock was the iconic festival. This criterion rules out the Beatles as the iconic rock band. And you have to tell a very different story if you use the Rolling Stones and Altamont.My Generation.Art school. An amazing number of English bands/musicians started/met in art school. Pete Townshend's fellow students at Ealing Art College included Ron Wood and Freddie Mercury.Destruction. In June 1964, Pete Townshend started the practice of destroying his guitar on-stage as part of his live performances. Keith Moon extended this to his drum set. And to hotel rooms....Roger Daltrey's fringed vest. And his scream.My Generation. And Won't Get Fooled Again.Keith Moon. Widely regarded as the greatest drummer in rock. Died of an overdose of clomethiazole while trying to control the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. Which, of course, makes him the iconic rock drummer. And drummers matter. I think it was Duke Ellington who explained this best: "In jazz, the drummer plays with the band. In rock, the band plays with the drummer."Loudness. The Guinness Book of World Records lists a 1976 concert by The Who in London as the loudest rock concert in history, at 126 decibels.The invention of the rock opera (Tommy; Quadrophenia).My Generation. And Won't Get Fooled Again. And Pictures of Lily. And Pinball Wizard. And Baba O'Riley....And that's all without even mentioning John Entwhistle, who was voted the greatest bass guitarist of all time in a 2011 Rolling Stone poll.

1. Rolling Stones - cover band, derivative, blues thieves, I don't care, I still listen to them regularly - Gimme Shelter is practically the second US National Anthem.2. Led Zeppelin - It is still hard hard rock. Will have you pulling apart the sofa looking for drugs 30 years after the fact. ==== 3. Beatles - I understand why people would rank them higher. Never been that into them myself. ==== 4. The Who5. Pink Floyd6. The Clash - 2nd album is kinda weak, everything else is strong EDIT: I see from some comments that the Clash might not be all that. I'm just old enough, early 40s, where the Clash is my Who or Led Zeppelin. By that time, the Who and Zep were the geezers so to speak. It's hard to overstate the impact The Clash, Black Market Clash and Sandinista had on my musical interests. Does that make them worthy or just personal? R.E.M. was better than U2 overall, but after around 1992 the music just wasn't as good/interesting to me. I still listen to the earlier stuff. First 3 records are perfection. I thought U2 was interesting at first, but overall, I don't think they are very good and do not really understand their success. After Joshua Tree, they just fell off for me. I don't even want to hear the old stuff. At the time though, I thought the first 3 records were pretty compelling. Maybe it was the Steve Lillywhite effect? They can't really make this list, but, man, I really like The Fall.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fall_(band) Since Van Halen I was a 1978 release, it's pretty easy to make a case that they had an absolute influence over the next ~15 years. That record was 1986 LA Glam, but in 1978. Impressive. Problem with them is 1984 sucked, and everything after that sucked too.

Top 5? Wow, I would have to think in terms of the innovators who actually steered the direction of Rock (IMHO) Let's start with this man. Yes I know you said bands, but he is among the early founders of what became rock and roll.  Elvis Presley, along with people like Little Richard, Bo Diddly, defined rock music in its seminal days. Elvis gave us the style and the swagger. Leather jackets, greaser hair and the gyrations.  The Beatles started with the raw material of rock and took the world on a trip. They were one of the biggest influences on culture in the 20th century and musically evolved the genre through the power ballad, screaming vocals, and pioneering psychadelic rock. What about these guys?  The Beach Boys brought us the endless Summer. While many couldn't commit to the moptop Beatles who made long hair and the hippy style the trend, these guys brought a wholesome look. But they brought much more. Tight harmonies and interesting music which in its own way evolved (check out Pet Sounds). They were also pioneers in studio technology. These were the guys I listened to in school:  Not the shmaltsy love song band of the eighties, but chicago the band of the early 70s that influenced people like Jimmy Hendrix. Their music was said to force Berklee School of music to rewrite their music theory course. Not only did they blend styles of Rock and jazz, but they brought complexity to the music through complicated harmonies and rhythm. Finally, if I had just one more band to choose it would be this one:  Rush took us on a musical journey of fantasy and energy. They were story tellers and dreamers who combined the complexities of the other innovators but defined the genre of the power trio. What a hard question to answer. So many choices and directions to take. A few controversial choices of my own and several that I can't imagine having to leave out. How could we have rock without Chubby Checker, Yes, Boston, Van Halen, not to mention the punk rockers, psychedelic rock, oh yeah and Frank Zappa. Thanks for letting me try.

I’m going to compromise and say The Rolling Stones. If the question was “Which is the greatest album rock band of all time” then the answer would be the Beatles. Their catalogue holds up better than any other artist. They came, they released 7 years of brilliant studio albums, and they left before they started releasing crap. All their albums are great and their influence can’t be denied. But their live shows were terrible. They were great, sloppy but great, in the early cavern days but in their successful era they played 25 minute sets where they had a bored run through of their standard set list to screaming audiences who couldn’t hear a word they sang. If the question was “What’s the greatest live band of all time” then my answer would be The Grateful Dead. There was nobody else like them and when they were “on” (which they were more often than not) their concerts were incredible. Nobody else could deliver three hours of incredible, improvised rock and roll and then return the next night and deliver a completely different, but just as good, three hours. There’s never been a live group like them before or since. But their albums were often terrible. American Beauty and Workingman’s Dead are both great, and I have a soft spot for their debut, but other than that they were clearly uncomfortable in the studio and less than the sum of their parts. Deadheads often ask each other what the best version of a certain song is. The answer is never “The studio version”. Every single song they ever recorded was topped by a live version, usually dozens of live versions. So I’d give the title of greatest band to the Rolling Stones based purely on the fact that they were the second best album and second best live band. Their sixties output is scattered with some of the best pop rock of the era and their incredible run of masterpieces (Let it Bleed, Beggars Banquet, Sticky Fingers and Exile on Mainstreet) is a run of brilliant albums that no other band has matched. Their work for the rest of the seventies was a step down but still outstanding. While it’s true their recorded output wasn’t as good in the eighties and nineties as it was in their prime, there are still a lot of gems there. They haven’t recorded anything as good as Sitcky Fingers since 1971, but to be fair, nobody else has either. Unlike the Beatles, they improved their music when they took it out onstage. Their live shows were incredible, Jagger is the greatest frontman in rock and roll and the only person on the planet who could steal attention away from Keith Richards. While their studio output isn’t what it once was, their live shows are still outstanding and a ferocious representation of the quality of their back catalogue. Sadly their live albums were generally poor representations of their shows and were usually made up of overdubbed tracks cobbled together into an experience that wasn’t a good representation of what he crowd enjoyed. Thankfully they have recently started to release archival live shows in full which showcase how good they were. If Brussells Affair had been released as a live album at the time it was recorded, instead of decades later, it would top Live At Leeds as the most highly regarded live album of all time. I hope the Stones have another great studio album in them and finish their career on a highpoint. 2012’s Doom and Gloom shows they can still write an oustanding song and an album of that quality would be an excellent note to finish their incredible career on.

Well, a question like this is impossible to answer with absolute certainty( maybe because it’s subjective;) ) but I’ll add my thoughts on it. From Rubber Soul onward, the Beatles catalogue is a treasure that will forever. Their music is something that always lifts my spirits, regardless of my circumstances. If you study their music, you’ll learn about some of the remarkable things they did with their sound and their songwriting. For anybody even with a remote interest in rock music, I highly recommend looking into how the Beatles wrote their songs. It’s a fascinating journey. I have to mention The Rolling Stones. While I believe a lot of their stuff is very mediocre, I can’t deny the fact that they were an absolute driving force back in the day. I watched a documentary describing the Rolling Stones sound as “audible testosterone”, a description I fully agree with. But when I think of testosterone, I imagine seeing someone speeding down the highway listening to “Immigrant Song” or “When the Levee Breaks”. While Zeppelin is primarily known for fist-pumping head bangers, their modest acoustic songs are, in my eyes, just as important to their legacy. While the Stones and Zeppelin are commonly the first bands to come to mind when thinking of classic rock and roll bands, The Who represent everything that makes rock and roll great. Their famous stage presence combined with their diverse range of songs make them legendary. They’ve been rockin’ with each other for a while now, which is pretty remarkable in and of itself. Then there’s Floyd. I can always rely on a chill Gilmour solo to raise my spirits, for he is the sage of guitar gods. Roger Waters, while not having the best public image, is a brilliant songwriter. They are one of the few bands with lyrics that really pierce your soul. Listening to “Nobody Home” compels me to start acting like an actor in a musical. Lastly, I’ll mention who is perhaps my favorite of the bunch, The Doors. Jim Morrison was a guy with the perfect balance of sophistication and flare. He is one of the few who naturally just compels you to start singing. What’s more, the group really knew how to JAM. I’ve always been impressed with their musicianship, and I still tend to get lost in the instrumental jams they did when I’m listening to them. Oh, I almost forgot about R.E.M. . This group could do it all, from euphoric rockers to beautifully melancholic ballads. I’m gonna come out and say that Michael Stipe is the best vocalist of all time. Is there anyone else who is as masterful at adapting his voice to the song as he is? I think they rival the Beatles when it comes to really taking your imagination on a joyride.

This is gonna be unexpected from me, since this band has not transferred over to my generation by and large, but I’m all in for Jethro Tull. I know what you’re thinking: 1) Who?? or 2) Pshh, you mean that weird band with the flute and the guy who dresses like a 19th century horseman? Precisely. And that man in question is Ian Anderson, who served as vocalist, flutist, and acoustic/rhythm guitarist for the band for its entirety (1967–2014). Here he is:  This guy is one of the best musicians in rock music. Not only did he write great lyrics and sing well (for the first 20 years, anyway), but he also played a whole plethora of instruments for music he composed almost singlehandedly. In addition to the instruments I mentioned, he also played keyboards, bass, mandolin, bouzouki, saxophone, and even occasional drums in the studio. The guy can do it all, as he showcased by steering the band through different genres such as blues rock (late 60s, early 70s), Progressive Rock (early-mid 70s), hard rock, folk rock (late 70s), and then 80s prog and hair type stuff (first and second half of the decade, respectively), before kind of simmering down to more progressive stuff in the 90s. This is why Jethro Tull is so great- how many rock bands do you know that have changed their sound so much over their time, and have done it amazingly? Of course, it isn’t ALL because of Ian. He had a great partner in crime in this guy:  This is Martin Barre, the longest-lasting member of the Jethro Tull family besides Ian himself. Martin joined in 1968 to record their second album, Stand Up, and lasted until Ian fired him in about 2014. His guitar style moved gracefully with the genre changes, and he nailed them all, even (and especially) the heavy, hair-metal kind of stuff in the late 80s. This man is criminally underrated as a musician, I think he’s better than Jimmy Page and Tony Iommi and guys like that. He lasted most of his career in Ian’s shadow, but his guitar work is unparalleled. Thanks to these two, Jethro Tull easily clears the others.

The greatest rock band of all-time? Easy. Led Zeppelin and I’ll tell you why they are the greatest. I understand Zeppelin is the choice among many for the greatest rock band of all-time, something of a favorite or a choice people who really don’t know anything about rock music pick, I think the fact that so many choose Zeppelin solidifies their greatness. The simple fact of the matter is that picking and choosing who is the GOAT is reserved for the general public, music writers rarely give such opinions and the musicians themselves are rarely a source of truth as they all somehow believe they are the greatest. With that being said, I believe that Zeppelin is the greatest because of three reasons. Their popularity has remained throughout their fifty year existence. Arguably they are more popular now than they were back in 1968. Don’t just put this off to bandwagon fans, although I am sure there are quite a few. Zeppelin remains popular for a reason and I believe that reason is their music. Just like the Beatles remain popular, so does Zepp.The quality of their music. Arguably, Zeppelin produced some of the finest sounding music ever. I don’t know if it is because of the sound recording techniques which Page used, but when you listen to Zepp’s music, there is a sound produced which isn’t like anything else.The songs themselves. Zeppelin wrote some incredible songs. The plagiarism stuff aside, Zeppelin wrote music which is still be used and highly desired today, the fact that it was used in a Marvel movie last year movies this point.Of course, these are just my reasons, entirely subjective.

Queen or Led Zeppelin. Guys put Opera, Funk, Reggae, Metal, Folk, original Rock’n’Roll, Blues, Jazz, Hard Rock, Aretha Franklin-kind of songs, classical music, etc etc. All the members were absolutely the best at what they were doing, during recording sessions Queen invented the Tape Delay effect used widely today. It has been scientifically proven like a year ago that Freddie Mercury is the greatest vocalist of all times, they measured the sonic speed of how he could jump from taking a very high pitch note (one of the highest in the world) down to totally different singing style, they actually measured the physical state of his throat and lungs, there are people with wide vocal ranges of course, but they are not even artists, random people from youtube with the similar vocal apparatus traits. But those findings just added a lot of love among the fans and brought thousand of new ones. Robert Plant’s vocals are unique, even now, his singing is momentary recognizable, he has I think top 5 unique voice that universal, skilled and sweet to the ear. Freddie stands somewhere there too. Both bands had a certified engineer, John Deacon actually put up from different radio parts the Vox amp for Brian May that he still uses on stage (one row of the amps or more is fake, empty, this has been done to fine-tune sound on the big venue). John Paul Jones from Zeppelin is kind of a magic man, he plays bass generally, but on the Stairway To Heaven live performance he has this organ with the legs keyboard just like on big church organs, and he plays the two keyboards parts, he plays his bass part with legs, — he just uses all of himself to play music, and has been constantly inventing stuff. Both bands musicians are sharp individuals, starting from John Bonham who unfortunately passed, who is still recognized as one of the best drummer in the world, to Brian May who actually doctored his guitar from god knows what pieces of junk, he borrowed his mom’s blouse buttons to make fret marks, it has a complex electronics, and around 15 years ago Gibson started manufacturing this “Red Special” guitar that was and is a hit on the market. Brian May never played any different guitar but acoustics. Queen guys, their line-up never changed since they became Queen, they’d play scrabble on their tour buses, when other rock stars were drowning in whiskey pools and choking on cocaine and dying of idiotic behavior. There were parties of course, but that was not the lifestyle. Led Zeppelin started working earlier a bit, so there were parties because they were the first along with The Rolling Stones, the real fandom (not mania) started to grow up in the audience, but everyone always managed to get to the venue on time and play their best. Well, Jimmy Page screwed up on stage a couple of times in the late 80’s or it was early 90’s, that was funny:) I think it is very important that each member of any band are approximately the same social level, I mean education, the families they descent from, those people wouldn’t invent punk, and even if they did, they’d ignore that because there are so many more interesting things like orchestral arrangements, soundtrack production, trying different things. The latter was the most important for Queen, — surely for Freddy, who between recordings managed to take part in a Royal Ballet, and just causally told the other guys that he is dancing in that avant-garde play, where he had to sing a song being held upside down, the piece of that got into the “I Want To Break Free” video. I could actually go on and on and on about those two, but I have to answer the question! So “Why” — see above. “Who” — Queen.

Choosing the “best” rock band purely on quality is highly subjective, so I’ll choose to interpret “best” as “most influential on the evolution of rock music.” The Beatles — their massive popularity sparked the British Invasion, which reinvented and re-imported rock n’ roll back to America. Couple that with their creativity and willingness to experiment, and it’s difficult to top them.The Rolling Stones — they gave the electrification of American blues mass appeal and added an element of danger that that Beatles didn’t particularly trade on.The Who — the pioneers of the rock concert not just as music, but as a show. Between Townsend smashing his guitar, Moon blowing up his drum kit, Daltrey twirling his mike over his head, and Entwistle keeping it all together while being a demon on bass, they even showed Hendrix a thing or two. Speaking of whom….The Jimi Hendrix Experience — because Hendrix broke the barriers of what an electric guitar could do.The Velvet Underground — all too unheralded and they weren’t around long, but they pioneered the concept of rock as a visual art form which led to Pink Floyd and prog rock, and explored subject matter most others wouldn’t. Their debut is hypnotic, even to this day.Led Zeppelin — the quintessential hard rock band; their debut was noticeably heavier than anything that came before it, and that’s not an exaggeration. They made Seventies rock what it was.Black Sabbath — more than any others, the inventors of heavy metal. Metal bands still tune down to this day because of Tony Iommi.

I’m an admitted music novice, including when it comes to the overwhelming (yet comparatively brief compared to other genres) history of rock n roll. There are quite a few bands that I’m simply not familiar enough with to consider, despite how great I’ve heard that they are (i.e. Metallica, Led Zeppelin, U2, and many others). That being said, here is my highly personal and entirely subjective rankings of, if not the best bands, certainly my favorites. The Beatles - Nothing to be said, really. Simply unparalleled.Radiohead - The greatest musicians of the modern age. This band has made some of the most emotionally powerful stuff I’ve ever heard, creating a great sense of existential anxiety and distance that, if you let it in, can become beautiful and warm and comforting, like being told you really aren’t alone. Their early stuff is great, but it really is Kid A and after is just on another level.The Velvet Underground - Second only to Bob Dylan, Lou Reed is my musical and especially lyrical hero (despite being an apparent misogynistic racist shit-bag in real life). The heroin shot of The Velvets in the era of love and LSD was like throwing an electric piranha in a bowl of stoned goldfish. But to compare them to a carnivorous fish is to ignore their sweeter, equally gorgeous side, the side of “I’ll Be Your Mirror”, “Pale Blue Eyes”, “Candy Says” and other classics.The Clash - Punk rock is often labelled nihilistic, but if there is any band to prove that stereotype wrong it’s this one. If I need a pick me up, a good dash of social unrest personified, or just a light at the end of a tunnel, I go to this band. There is not band more idealistic and committed than The Clash.Nirvana - This has been a recent fixation for me, but I think they are certainly worthy of being in the conversation. No one gets teen angst like these guys (the closest second might be Violent Femmes) and to be able to get across such misery and anger without seeming like they’re faking it or coming through as whiney or melodramatic is an achievement in itself.Honorable Mentions: The Pixies, The Kinks, Sex Pistols, Talking Heads, Bob Marley and the Wailers, The Jimi Hendrix Experience, The Strokes, The Beach Boys, R.E.M.

The Beatles. The whys are answered here on nearly a daily basis. If not for the Beatles there would unlikely have been any other huge bands. Bands such as the Rolling Stones would not sound as they do to us as they would not have progressed past the blues they began with. The British music Invasion probably would not have happened so most of us wouldn't even know who those bands were. The Beatles were responsible for the influence and inspiration of most of the musicians of their time and since. They were at the forefront of most of the musical genres we listen to today. They were at the forefront of fashion. They conquered the whole damned world without firing a shot but by singing a few songs. They went from being mortals to immortals and their musical legacy has reached mythical proportions. They were four of the most talented individuals to ever come together in a band and had four of the most diverse personalities and yet complimented one another perfectly. The songwriting team of John Lennon&Paul McCartney is considered to be the greatest songwriting team of all time. Most bands have a frontman The Beatles had three. They had two of the greatest vocalists of any band in Lennon and McCartney. They had a third great vocalist and songwriter in George Harrison. Richard Starkey aka Ringo Starr was a great drummer and a pleasant vocalist. They had what most other bands didn't, a deep love for one another that never diminished even after the roller coaster ride ended and the bubble burst. No one at the time compared with them. No one ever will.

Oh, hell. I guess it depends on how you define greatness. Probably financially, longevity-wise, and the continued quality of the shows, all things considered, I’d probably give it to the Stones, in spite of the rough patches. If you’re talking about creating a fairly tight and devoted fan base, the Dead probably pulled that off. The Beatles probably get it for moving pop music closer to fine art (and we’re talking Rubber Soul /Revolver until the end) than anyone else, and for practically inventing a new production aesthetic. The Beach Boys, and let’s face it, I’m talking about Brian Wilson, are also up there in the revolution of studio craftsmanship, and I probably would say Steely Dan gets a nod for taking cues from both of those groups and becoming so dictatorial in the studio that engineers still use those recordings to EQ auditoriums. Now, if we’re talking about the Big Bang that was the creation of the whole genre, even though Elvis was the breakthrough point and the world would forever in one way or another view the world of rock and roll through Elvis -colored lenses (if you don’t believe me, just compare the cover of the first Elvis LP with the cover of The Clash’s “London Calling”), I think Little Richard wins the prize as a performer, as an innovator, and planting so many seeds that bore the fruit of so many sub-genres: Motown, Soul, funk, immediately spring to mind, but there’s not a country-rock piano player, nor heavily made-up glam rocker, or outlandish showman (looking at you, Marilyn Manson) that doesn’t owe the man a debt. I spent a little time thinking about including some music from a later time period than I have used in this particular analysis, but with only minor deviations, these artists created the templates of modern music, and I imagine that those people who freaked out about Public Enemy in the ‘80’s could not have been more freaked than the average American seeing Tina Turner shake it during prime time in 1968. I also realize that I didn’t include any female artists except for Tina, and for that I can only offer the limp but true excuse that women, though always a (usually undervalued) presence from Elizabeth Cotten to Diana Ross to Joan Jett, have had to fight their way onto trails that they often found had been credited to others, often under the (ugly) assumption that female performers were little more than pretty dolls wound up to play by and for men. This is certainly not the case, but I’m sure that any feminist reading of the history of Rock and Roll will rightly point out that it was, and sadly to some extent still remains, a boy’s club in the popular imagination, if not reality.

I have been into rock music for a really long time and it certainly tickles my fancy. Rock music is a genre of popular music that originated as "rock and roll" in the USA in the 1950s, and developed into a range of different styles in the 1960s and later, particularly in the UK, the US, Canada and Australia. Musically, rock centres on the electric guitar, usually as part of a rock group with electric bass guitar and drums.Typically, rock is song-based music usually with a 4/4 time signature using a verse-chorus form, but the genre has become extremely diverse.Rock places a higher degree of emphasis on musicianship, live performance, and an ideology of authenticity than pop music.Rock is best played at volume 11I have listed just few examples that I think demonstrates “Rock” as a genre. Voodoo Child (Slight Return) - Jimi Hendrix Helter Skelter - Beatles The White Room - Cream Whole Lotta Love - Led Zeppelin We Wont Be Fooled Again - The Who Can’t Me Knocking - Rolling Stones Now I’m Here - Queen Barracuda - Heart Back in Black - AC/DC Welcome to the Jungle - Guns and Roses Love Spreads - The Stone Roses Enter Sandman - Metallica Killing in the Name - Rage Against the Machine Come As you Are - Nirvana 7 Nation Army - White Stripes Rock music - Wikipedia

The Beatles - They changed music, forever. Love them or hate them, they took us from soft, country-esque sound to hard rock, in 6 years. No other group has been as influential and prolific as they were. Led Zeppelin - The band that defined what being a rock and roll band should be. If it’s Tuesday, this must be Belgium. They filled stadiums, sold albums, didn’t bend for commercial needs, and they stand as musical giants some 40 years after their last album. RUSH - The musical geniuses from Canada. Every album has been platinum. As a trio, they have the world’s best drummer, one of the best bassists ever to touch a string, and a grossly underrated guitarist, simply because he shares his stage with legends. Pink Floyd - Piper at the Gates of Dawn through The Final Cut - they embody what it is to be progressive rock. A band defined by their sound, who’s members had been nearly anonymous throughout their career. Dark Side of the Moon stands as one of the best selling albums of all time, with an unprecedented 1630 weeks (31 years) on the charts, with 937 weeks (18 years straight) as a top 200 seller. The Jimi Hendrix Experience - It’s hard to overstate the influence of this band. They are the quintessential hippy rock band. Jimi changed what it meant to be a guitarist, and their catalogue of hits is impressive. These folks, in my mind, are the absolute giants of rock and roll. Nobody else comes close. While there are many other talented musicians, or famous bands, nobody else can claim the influence on music that these 5 can.

I have a number of answers to this. Subjective answers… Pink Floyd; As I consider the Wall the greatest rock and roll album, I can argue Pink Floyd to be the greatest rock band; The Wall surpasses mere rock and roll though; It’s unique; Also, Dark Side of the Moon was the best selling and top rated rock album for a very long timeRolling Stones; Why not? They have many hit songs; They may have failed to evolve with the times, but that doesn’t stop them from having one of the largest sets of songs played on commercial radio, of any band, indicating how strong they are ( Just ignore boring songs like Satisfaction and instead listen to Paint it Black, etc.)U2; So many great songs and so many hits; One of the most famous “socially conscious bands”; But I put this in as a whim, I don’t expect much agreementAerosmith; Ok, not the greatest rock band ever, perhaps; But one of the greatest American rock bands; They had a ton of hit songs, and reinvented themselves a few times; Toys in the Attic is still impressive to me, and when people are patting Guns and Roses on the back for Appetite for Destruction’s hard edge sound, just listen to Toys in the Attic!Not the Beatles; No way, not for me; I grant the many reasons people will put them #1, and hell, there’s good reason to do so. But I find them boring for the most part, which is the opposite of why I like rock & roll; They are more pop than rock to me, whatever that means; I grant songs like Day in the Life are great in a way, but not in a rock and roll way; not to me

Of course there is no correct answer, my contribution goes something like this … All of the Big Names are likely contenders. There is also a difference between recording and performing bands. I am a huge fan of Deep Purple, but I’ve seen some footage of concerts that were not always riveting. Led Zeppelin were a very successful and magnetic live act. The Beatles were immensely relevant in writing and recording but had a relatively short “live” presence in their recording heyday. The Stones alway entertained. Pink Floyd recordings and concerts have a huge atmosphere. AC-DC were one of the most phenomenal bands in concert I’ve ever seen. I’m not a huge Queen fan, but they were a superb mix or recording and performance presence. I love the Beach Boys… some immensely wonderful music, largely via the genius of Brian Wilson. Are they a rock band? Special honourable mentions: • Free (recordings and live, check the Isle of Wight festival) • Jethro Tull • Yes • Little Feat • Doobie Bros • The Who. An awful lot will come down to how old you are! And who influenced you most. If I had to be purist, and use “rock” as the prime delineator, Led Zep might be ahead by a nose…..as many of my other fave bands are probably not entirely “rock.”

There are way too many ways to answer this question. First of all, let's assume you mean English-language rock music, an assumption based on the language and placement of the question.  And we'll presume that "band" precludes any solo artists, including those that perform under a band-like moniker (like John Ondrasik's Five for Fighting or Trent Reznor's Nine Inch Nails). I guess the question behind the question here is what defines being the "best."  Makes the best music?  Most influential?  Biggest impact? For technical skill, I'd probably lean towards bands like Rush, Yes, Bela Fleck and the Flecktones, Dream Theater, and Van Halen, and between those I'd probably have to choose Union-era Yes, based on sheer band member numbers, but I'm sure plenty of people could construct well-argued alternatives.  For example, a very compelling argument could be made for a band like Queen, which combines skilled musicianship with otherworldly vocal talent. For collective musical talent, it's hard to find a more impressive group than USA for Africa ("We Are The World").  With Bruce Springsteen, Bob Dylan, Hall & Oates, Michael Jackson, Smokey Robinson, Tina Turner, Ray Charles, Harry Belafonte, Willie Nelson, Dionne Warwick...the list goes on and on.  Though you could probably make a similar argument for Bob Geldof's Band Aid ("Do They Know It's Christmas"), as well as Artists for Haiti ("We Are The World 25 for Haiti"). For overall talent (musical and non-musical), I'd probably choose another celebrity supergroup, Voices that Care ("Voices That Care").  Besides the (by comparison) modest list of vocal leads, the supporting choir includes the likes of Michael Jordan, Wayne Gretzky, Magic Johnson, Tommy Lee Jones, Whoopi Goldberg, Meryl Streep, and dozens more highly talented celebrities (though it's not clear whether they actually all performed on the song itself).  You could probably still argue for both USA for Africa and Artists for Haiti under this criteria as well. This is the point at which things take a decidedly Beatlesesque flavor. For album sales, The Beatles win hands down, having sold more units than  both of the next two bands on the list (Led Zeppelin and Pink Floyd)  combined.  For impact, creative breadth, longevity, and influence, it's hard to  argue with The Beatles - which is why they're the most commonly given answer to this  sort of question.  For half a century the Beatles have been widely accepted as the root of modern musical influence, and even those that argue alternatives always have to argue against The Beatles, essentially disproving their point.  (That said, the followup meta question -- but who influenced The Beatles? -- is fairly interesting, as the most obvious band to do so is The Beach Boys, who could be said to have driven The Beatles to ultimately become the super-influential band they were, and were a pretty talented bunch themselves.) In terms of popularity, The Beatles likely top the list again, both for height and longevity.  There have been crazes to rival Beatlemania (New Kids on the Block, anyone?), but no group has equaled that level of success.  (Well, perhaps Michael Jackson or Elvis, but alas, neither qualifies as a band.)  And the Beatles are still revered today, in a way that borders on musical religion. But finally there's the big one: who makes the best music?  Sure, I could go down the path of trying to qualify which band's music is better than all others, but I really feel like the answer is whoever's music you like most right now.  Musical enjoyment's underlying subjectivity means you like who you like.  Whoever manages to give you the best version of whatever it is you like, for you, is the best band ever, even if it's They Might Be Giants one day, Two Door Cinema Club the next...and One Direction when your 10-year-old niece is over. So the answer is The Beatles...maybe, but probably not, depending on what you mean by "best," and who you're asking. Hope that clears things up for you. =) (reposted from What is the best band of all-time?)

Here’s my answer on why it’s (drum roll …) The Beatles: Thomas J. Beaver's answer to Why are The Beatles considered the best music artists of all time? Start with this: The Beatles had 30 #1’s (singles) and 34 (additional) Top Ten hits. In 1963–66, a span of four years, The Beatles had 18 #1 albums in at least one country (the US, UK, Australia, Germany, France, or Canada). A unique feat. From the 13th of February, 1964 through May 9th, The Beatles held the Billboard #1 spot for 85 consecutive days, one song after the other. A unique feat. In April 1964, the Beatles had all five of the Billboard Top Five singles: Can’t Buy Me Love, Twist and Shout, I Want to Hold Your Hand, She Loves You, and Please Please Me. A unique feat. In 1965, when “Ticket to RIde” went to #1 in the USA, it was the 7th consecutive #1 single (US charts) that was a Beatles song. A unique feat. Musically, in 1963–64 they brought the Chuck Berry/Little RIchard — combines with the Everlys — style of rock to the US audience. Then, with the help of producer George Martin, the ‘5th Beatle’, they led the pop world into becoming more and more avant garde, particularly in the 1966–67 era. John Lennon and Paul McCartney broke through as the best songwriting duo around, and probably (arguably) in history. Once George Harrison developed into the top songwriter he became as well (circa 1967), The Beatles had three elite songwriters in one band … a unique feat as well. I could go on and on … but that’s a good start.

In no order, who would you say are the top five rock bands of all time? Depends on how you define “top five”. Stadium ticket sales? Biased towards higher prices in recent years - a single Stones stadium show at $200 a ticket can do better than an entire Beatles national tour. Even “number of tickets sold” is biased - Beatles at Shea Stadium could only fit 50,000 people in the venue, while larger stadiums today can crowd in 100,000. And then you get free open-air concerts where you get 1 to 3 million people listening, and Woodstock 69 where 30,000 tickets got sold but 300,000 people showed up… Number of albums sold? Things get skewed - “Frampton Comes Alive” was an OK album, but sold *way* more than its quality would have predicted. Number of singles or albums that hit the top 10? There’s tons of major classic rock bands that never hit the top 10. Hell, even Led Zeppelin only had *one* single ever hit the top 10. Amount of popularity compared to other bands in their era? The word Beatlemania was invented for a reason. Amount of popularity 20 or 40 years after they did their music? See Rolling Stones. :) (And today I saw that Judas Priest announced their 50th anniversary tour for next year….) Amount of impact on contemporary artists? A band called Van Halen released a single called Eruption back in 1978, and pretty much every other guitarist on the planet said “Wait, what?” Amount of impact on other artists that came later? Poster child here is Robert Johnson, who you probably never heard of because he recorded 29 songs in crappy mono sitting in a hotel room somewhere in Texas back in 1936 and 1937. And I can probably come up with some other definitions, like “the bands I listen to the most now” and “the bands I’ve listened to the most over the past half century” and “the bands I most like to listen to” And yes, there’s a difference between “bands I listen to the most” and “bands I like to listen to the most” - when you’re spending 8 hours a day in a cubicle farm with music on to drown out office noise, Tangerine Dream is a better choice than something like Ramones that’s likely to get you singing along with it… :)

You won’t get a straight answer from anyone for the following reason. Your question is one of a moving target. There have certainly been many extremely good rock and roll acts, but they are all reflections of a particular time and place. People today seem to look at the sixties like it invented rock and roll when all that happened was there was a major social upheaval across the country that was reflected in the popular musical expressions of the moment. Rock and roll has been a fulcrum if you will, a place where people seem to put all their focus, expecting it to represent some kind of definitive cultural statement. However, that is never going to happen in this country for one simple reason. Popular music for the last hundred years has been dominated by commercial interests, and anytime money defines a cultural expression it is instantly tainted and no longer an accurate reflection of society. This has happened countless times and thus you can really only comment, and only subjectively, about any particular greatest rock group at any point in time. There for, although the Beatles changed the face of rock and roll popular music along with, and no less than countless other groups that were more or less prolific, you really can’t say that they were the greatest rock group ever anymore than any other group at any other time. Of course the Rolling Stones are very good, but so were The Yardbirds. This kind of speculation is like trying to “prove” that Charlie Parker was a better saxophone player than Sydney Bechet. They were both superb, both successful and famous and performed music that reflected different generations of musical audiences. Music is a snapshot of what is going on socially and always has been. Before the sixties period, and overlapping with the fifties were producers with stables of songwriters and performers like Phil Spector, who was far from the only one. If we switch the question to classical cello players it was thought for a long time that Pablo Casals was the greatest cello player in the world, but then Yo Yo Ma was not performing yet, at least not for the size of audience he has today and I would dare anyone to try to make the comparison. In the final analyses this kind of argument is like the Olympics where some athlete performs some activity in a quarter of a second faster than someone else so they get the gold medal. Are they actually the best? I would argue that there is more to being the best than that. It looks to me like quite often an awful lot of people are the best in any given field. There is no band that can accurately be given that title in my opinion because the question does not allow for such a rigid answer to be given.

Beatles… for so many reasons. Even if you don’t like their music (what is wrong with you?)… EVERY band you love most likely started because of the Beatles. Their Ed Sullivan appearance launched a thousand bands. Example? Black Sabbath started out as a Beatles cover band! They were called Earth (and more briefly, Rare Earth) at the time. Ozzy does a pretty great cover of ‘In My Life’.  Also, they single-handedly changed the entire record business. Before them, bands didn’t write and perform their own songs. Google ‘brill building’ for this. Beatles kind ruined everything… by writing and performing and singing their own songs. AND being wildly charismatic. I trace the ENTIRE ‘singer/ songwriter’ movement to the Beatles. After the Beatles, people expected musicians to write their own music. This has reverted, btw. You think Rhianna and Katy Perry and write their own songs? Not by a mile. If for no other reason… watch their press conference when the got to America. It is BRILLIANT. How funny these guys were, just on the fly, is scary. RINGO: "Well, we run quicker than the English ones, we'll have a go here, you know." This was the first time America got to see and hear them in person. We were smitten, instantly

I think this is too subjective to even attempt to answer. Greatest on what count— Emotionality? Melody? Virtuosity? Lyrics? People reached? Message? Style? Riffs? Tightness? Production? Popularity? Prolonged popularity? Hair? And every single one of those will have vastly different opinions from EVERYONE. Now, if you want my personal favorite rock band, that’s a whole different matter. But to assume my personal favorite is the absolute greatest of all time, when there is not an absolute standard for measuring something such as “musical greatness”, is absolutely foolhardy and cocky. Which is why I would word this question completely differently. But I’ll answer about my favorites. Stryper is probably my first all time favorite. By first, I mean, first in chronological order, not necessarily favoritism. Stryper is a Christian hair metal band and they undoubtedly had an influence on me in my younger years and today. They looked like other bands I liked, and they were Christian like me and made songs I liked. As time passed, I’ve grown less into Hair Metal itself, but I do not believe I will ever completely move on from it. They were and still are a band, they had all the original members back for a while, but unfortunately some different things caused them to have to part ways with their bass player, and now one of their guitarists has recently had a seizure and is recovering. A really cool side note is a Hair metal band called W.A.S.P. I wouldn’t recommend going back and listening to any of their older stuff, as it’s not exactly appropriate in any way, however the reason I mentioned them is their lead singer became Christian and is now producing very Godly music, which is such a super cool thing! As they say, there is unimaginable rejoicing in heaven every time someone who is lost comes back. My favorite band today would probably be A Day to Remember. They aren’t really Christian, but I love their music and they are pretty responsible as far as bands go. They inspired me in many ways musically and remain one of my most loved bands. They are what got me into singing and screaming music. I’ve never been too much for all screaming music— I enjoy contrast and different moods and dynamics more than an all out continual beatdown— but I can respect and get into some of it. I do shy away from the stuff that gets stupidly violent or obscene, though. That doesn’t seem particularly healthy, to me. There are different ways of thinking about it, but I guess we have to be careful our “release outlet” doesn’t become the very validating source of our fetishes. If you like 80s or 2000s electronic music, or Pop-punk, or just energetic music, I recommend The New Cities first album Lost In City Lights. Every song on that is just so melodic and catchy to me, I love it a lot. They went WAY more electronic and pop on their next album, but this first album is really cool, just enough guitar to be awesome to me, perhaps it reflects the changes in popular music landscape, at one point the pseudo punk (whatever you wanna call it, no offense intended) thing was popular, but then popular music kinda switched a little bit more towards total electronic dance for a while. Now it’s like in-between, today. But also a lot of rap type things. Now you can go and find someone else who likes the total opposite of all these bands. Have fun, Ya’ll! Blessings

If it comes down to 5 choices, I think this is a less controversial question than meets the eye. I don't agree with Charlie Cheever w.r.t. several of his "strong-case" suggestions (Phish, Radiohead (band), Queen, Yardbirds, Aerosmith (band)). No way these bands have a shot at the "greatest bands ever" title. And I don't agree with the relativist suggestions that... no answer is the right one; the answer depends on taste; it's a splintered set of choices; etc. In my opinion, you have to play stadiums to qualify for this list, which I believe includes: BeatlesU2 (band)The Rolling Stones (band)Led Zeppelin (band)The Who (band)Of this list, I feel that The Who is the most vulnerable to displacement.  Potential alternatives for the #5 slot include: Bruce Springsteen and the E-Street Band (per Jacob Sommer)Grateful Dead (band)Pink Floyd (band)RushThe Clash (band)The Jimi Hendrix Experience (per User)I wouldn't pick any of these four bands for my list, but I believe that each has a meaningful plurality of fans who would support them over The Who.    I also have a personal fondness for Nirvana and Metallica, but neither is a serious contender for the Greatest of All Time title.
